title: Which presidential candidate will win Arizona?
preds: There's a higher turnout of votes this year than 2016. Many young latinos are old enough to vote and they are majority Ds.  Also, there's many signs across the Phoenix area that are "Arizona Republicans for Biden" and Biden signs in suburban yards.
Biden has the edge here too.
No indication that Biden is gaining traction in state.

Biden's lead has been getting narrower in the last weeks. Still think he will win, but lowering my prediction.  Biden: -20
Trump: +20
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/arizona/ Note to self: match 538 or go bigger? which is the better strategy?
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

Biden still has an advantage, though polling-wise it is within the margin of error for a race of this size. Given the duration of his lead and Trump's dwindling support in key voting blocs in the state, I think Biden comes out ahead here.

Polls have tightened by Biden is still the clear favorite.

Adjusting this down since the crowd and 538 have also adjusted it down, since I'm not smarter than either the crowd or 538. However, I should point out that early voting has been going on since October 7th and over a quarter of Arizona's registered voters have already cast their ballots in the state, during a period in which Biden has been up 3-4 points in the polling averages. Even assuming a 75% turnout, this means election day is already 1/3 completed! These early votes have favored Biden, and these are votes that are locked in. https://www.politico.com/news/2020/10/23/early-voting-numbers-swing-states-431363
Also, there has been a huge upsurge in votes by people under 30: https://circle.tufts.edu/latest-research/absentee-and-early-voting-youth-2020-election
Biden looks good to win this state.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.
Forecast autogenerated; see profile for details.

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Arizona by 1.8 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 47.8% for trump to Biden's 49.5%. Seven day momentum was in Biden's favor, improving his position by 0.6%.
3.9% difference in polls. Biden leading more often than DT. Keeping the forecast unchanged

Biden continues to hold a 4 point advantage, won the first debate by almost every metric worth considering, won both the second debate (as his opponent forfeited) and the "dueling town halls" with both a wider viewership and clearer message, and continues to gain support in key demographics. Trump has insulted minorities and seniors in recent weeks, both of which are needed to win Arizona (and almost every other swing state) so he's really not doing himself any favors.

I've been split 50/50 on this, but with ~2 weeks left until the election Biden seem to have a both healthy and stable lead over Trump, so with the small amount of time left to the election I'm going with Biden. The Democratic candidate: +30
The Republican candidate: -30
Going down a little bit over https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2020/11/what-if-trump-refuses-concede/616424/

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

In 2016, trump beat last RCP average in Arizona by 1.8 points. Using this as a handicap and averaging out RCP current average, 270towin current average , Economist prediction and 538 prediction, you have a project result of 47.95% for trump to Biden's 48.55%. Seven day momentum was in trump's favor, improving his position by 0.97%.

My guess is that with debates, COVID-19,  tax revelations, the probabilities of Trump losing would be going up, including this one. Also, I am compensating for my lack of participation in this question.

Probably too high here with Dem averaging 3.7% lead in RCP polls.  Inside view is a blue wave.

Voting starts in Arizona on October 1st. So we are going to have to combine a  bunch of datasets to be accurate about this.  ~~~~~~~~~~~~
Outside View :
~~~~~~~~~~~~
Biden is up currently by 3.9 points on average when all the opinion polls are being averaged together [1]. There are currently 1.38 Million Registered Republicans in Arizona, 1.29 MIllion Democrats, and 1.2 Million Undecided Voters [2]. Off all of those people only 75 percent showed up in 2016 [2]. In 2016 Trump  was up by 4 points in the polls [3]. However Trump only won by 94,000 votes [4], which isn't that much.  ~~~~~~~~~~
Inside View:
~~~~~~~~~~ Arizona has an elderly population of about 15.8 percent of the population, of that percentage over 7.7 percent of the population of voting for Trump. Given that the Trump administration is botching the recovery of it the Coronavirus, I see that percentage of voters changing. So let's call that maybe 6.7 percent of the population will vote against Trump, and absentee voting starts in October for Arizona.  Given the large population of Independents in Arizona, 58 percent of independents disapprove of the job that Trump has done. Furthermore, Independents in Arizona are willing to vote for Biden at a rate of 55 percent, while only 38 percent are voting for Trump [6].  Given that voting is starting in Two Months of Arizona, assuming if things go perfectly for the administration that they could clean up the Coronvirus by then, which the changes are lower than 5%. The swing votes are more likely to start coming in for Biden earlier than they are for Trump so it seems more likely that Biden will win.  1. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/arizona/
2. https://azsos.gov/elections/voter-registration-historical-election-data
3. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/az/arizona_trump_vs_clinton-5832.html
4. https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/11/18/more-arizona-voters-didnt-equal-more-votes-donald-trump-hillary-clinton/93805952/
5. https://www.infoplease.com/us/census/arizona/demographic-statistics
6. http://maristpoll.marist.edu/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/NBC-News_Marist-Poll-AZ-NOS-and-Tables_202007231249.pdf

When voters in Kingman(!) are even considering voting for Biden, Trump is likely in trouble in the Grand Canyon State.

If Arizonans’ memories last more than 4 months, one would think they would break for Biden and Kelly in November, if only to repudiate Trump’s anti-mask rhetoric and assert their desire to live through the pandemic.
Ultimately voters will choose a candidate who is more predictable during this time of unpredictability, but Biden's choice for VP will dramatically influence these odds.

AZ will be interesting to watch. No, I don't think there is a 2% chance of someone else... I think there is no chance of that, rather I think both candidates are currently equally unlikely. Biden is polling well which just means Trump would be polling better by literally doing nothing. Who knows..?

Recent polls though generally give Biden a slight lead, so it may depend on how accurate that is and if that lead can be maintained into November.

Most people that will vote for the winning candidate will do so because of their long term needs. What we see on tv and in the news is the 5% of people that are driven by groupthink vs. a national, calm, dialog to press change upon America. That started, if the Democratic party ever held an open discussion about moving people from poverty and they stuck with that plan, they would win hands down. As of now, the process is an embarrassment to the history of America.

Arizona is traditionally a republican strong hold which is what I'm basing most of my prediction on. 
I don't put much trust in the recent weeks polls showing a lead for Biden. Trump was ahead for most of March which shows Biden's lead isn't cemented. Right now USA is going through several crisis at the same time, but I expect BLM protests to slow down at the latest at the end of summer and while the pandemic will be here in autumn I expect people to have reached some sort of normalcy in regards to it. Therefore election history still seem to me to be the best indication for the vote.

Current polling suggests Biden at 57% chance to win. Will bump given recent national events and drop in Trump's approval rating. Arizona more likely than Florida to go to Biden given its proximity to other West Coast liberal states.

Biden has been polling above Trump in AZ since March [1]. Even Fox has Biden up by 4 points [2]. While Trump should have the advantage, it looks like it may be pushing democratic, and Biden may be helped by the Senate race in AZ, in which Kelly is polling around 10 points ahead of McSally [3].
